citeinfo.title: A Spatial and Genetic Analysis of Cowbird Host Selection

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Geological Survey, Biological Resources Division, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center

citeinfo.origin: U.S. Geological Survey, Biological Resources Division, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center
citeinfo.title: Brood Parasitism on Neotropical Migrants

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Geological Survey, Biological Resources Division, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center

descript.abstract: Molecular genetics makes it possible to measure basic, but long elusive parameters of the breeding biology of the Brown-headed Cowbird (Molothrus ater). Cowbird fecundity and host selection behavior were examined using a combination of molecular genetic techniques to link female cowbirds to the eggs they lay, radio-telemetry techniques to track female cowbirds' daily movements, and geographic information systems (GIS) to integrate these genetic and spatial data. The study site lies within a forested 1300 ha landscape in New York composed primarily of mature forest with adjacent old fields. It was found that female cowbirds used their home ranges as principal egg-laying areas. Individual females used characteristic individual home ranges throughout the breeding season, and they returned to the same home range every breeding season. Over one-half (54%) of females laid all their eggs in host nests inside or close to their home range. Proximity to a females' home range was the only significant ecological or biological feature affecting a cowbird's host.
descript.purpose: Data Set purpose was to measure parameters of breeding biology of the Brown-headed Cowbird (Molothrus ater).
descript.supplinf:
Information for this metadata was adapted from the U.S. Geological Survey, Biological Resources Division, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center Showcase site at http://www.pwrc.usgs.gov/resshow/hahn1rs/hahn1rs.h tm. Internal Filename - usgsbrdpwrc0021; This is the "child" metadata for the larger work, Brood parasitism on Neotropical Migrants, Caldwell Hahn - Internal Filename - usgsbrdpwrc00000013. A digital copy of this metadata file is available in text, html, and sgml format on the National Biological Information Infrastructure (NBII) Metadata Clearinghouse.
The previous online linkage was determined to be broken in October 2010 and moved here. The previous online linkage was:
http://www.pwrc.usgs.gov/resshow/hahn1rs/hahn1rs.h tm

method.methdesc: Cowbird fecundity and host selection behavior were examined using a combination of molecular genetic techniques to link female cowbirds to the eggs they lay, radio-telemetry techniques to track female cowbirds' daily movements, and geographic information systems (GIS) to integrate these genetic and spatial data.
Conducted molecular genetic analyses of blood samples 1993 -1997. One more genetic analysis planned.

This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from a U.S. Geological Survey server, and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way.
